response:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: You can use the Iterator.next() method to get the current Item in your Linked List of Item objects.
<<<explanation>>>: Yes, creating an Item object within your class and setting it equal to the "current" Item when you wish to refer to it is a good approach. You can then use the .getAt(i) method to get the current Item at a specific index in your Linked List. If you want to set the attributes of one Item to another, you can override the equals() and hashCode() methods in your Item class to ensure that two Items are equal based on their attributes.
